comments.commentBody: I enjoyed this puzzle. Quick and fairly easy, but with a nice surprise.
Whoops: "America..."

Baloney! The Times needs to do a reality check on the weaknesses of a Clinton campaign in middle American and the relatively few people who are coming out to vote in these primaries. The former secretary of state may be a big liability to the Democratic Party in November...
Whoops: "America..."

First Bernie Sanders said it would be wrong for Hillary Clinton to use the super delegates to win the nomination. Now that he's losing, he says he plans to change super delegates' minds so that he can win the nomination with super delegates. His moral compass must have passed through a magnetic field.
Even less likely that you'll see any mention about Hillary carrying Northwest Indiana area (Gary, Hammond, etc) and why that matters.
I blame the media for giving him so much free advertising. The Times may say Clinton is their pick, but they go home with Donald.
The season of Trump. We all deserve this for not being more involved / not demanding more from our government.

It's not surprising Hillary spent little money in Indiana. Why would she have to, when the MSM historically has spent so much time glossing over information about Bernie and touting her. By this point in the campaign she is a shoo in because of the complicity of the MSM.
I just sent my 5th donation to the Bern!  Congrats.

Dana, get a grip! The Clintons are the most entitled couple in public life--and among other he least trusted, polls show--because it is widely understood that it is their overweening personal ambition that drives them, not the public interest.

Sanders, by contrast--like Elizabeth Warren--has been devoted to serving the public interest his whole career. He's not in this for himself, as is apparent to all who know him--he's in it to preserve what's left of American democracy from the greed and megalomania of the oligarchy in BOTH Parties.

When he argues that he has a better chance of winning the general election than Hillary, he's stating a FACT--established by poll after poll after poll!

Democratic Party insiders are determined to force Hillary's nomination, nonetheless...counting on everyone else "having no choice" but to vote for one of the most widely disliked candidates since Nixon, rather than to see Trump become President.

It's a dangerous game, but they're willing to chance losing the Election with the candidate they own, rather than winning it with one they don't. If they blow this election with their intransigence, they may well set the Democratic Party back a generation. Remember the cautionary injunction, "Pride goeth before the fall."
California. Please, PLEASE weigh in.

In the face of perhaps the greatest threat to the political order as we know it, the Democrats are putting up... the most unpopular candidate their party could find.

What on earth are they thinking? The future of the country and the planet are quite literally at stake, and Democrats are engaged in some kind of myopic, feel-good political exercise. When Trump dissolves the Supreme Court or sets up internment camps for Muslims, we can all look back and marvel at how wonderful it was to nominate a woman!

Wake up! Donald Trump is on the verge of becoming the leader of the free world! And you're going to nominate someone who is widely disliked and can't stick to a political position for more than 15 minutes?

The Democrats are knowingly giving Trump a shot at the White House that he would not have with really any other Democratic candidate. That may not be complicity, but it is surely gross negligence.

Trumps lack of functional knowledge about the world and civics in general will doom him in November. He will not be able to engage in chop fights and innuendo and insults in the general election. In the GOP primaries that sort of thing was fine, but in the general election he will need something he does not possess.That being functional knowledge about civics and the world. The USA is not a business he can run into the ground.

So you have been drinking the same kool-Aid as the rest of the Trump voters.  "Trump gets it" Really? Scotland did not see any spike in the jobs he promised his golf course would create. Nor did the students who coughed up thousands of dollars attending Trump University witness any signicant improvements in their job prospects. There are countless such examples - not least his many declared bankruptcies depleting the coffers of the U.S. Treasury. So no he really doesn't get what average Americans are going through. Please don't fall prey to his empty rhetorics.

I am neither a Drumpf supporter or a Margaret Thatcher II supporter because I don't support crony capitalist, politically expedient warmongers, but "Thatcher" and Drumpf have a heck of a lot more in common than Drumpf and Sanders. If Thatcher is willing to accept thousands of dollars in contributions from Drumpf for all of her past campaigns and for the Clinton Foundation than who else is Thatcher going to accept money from regardless of the strings that are attached? Saudi Arabian terrorists who kill Yemeni civilians? Oh, wait... She's already done that as the SoS. All Drumpf has to say in a general is that he donated money to Thatcher's past campaigns and to her foundation and that he effectively owns her. And guess what? The Democratic Senatorial and House election committees have also accepted donations from Drumpf, as well. Imagine that. If you really can't see how corrupt the Democratic Party is, you aren't wearing your glasses. It's all a game to Drumpf and Thatcher and we're they're pawns. Well, guess what? I'm not about to be a pawn in their game of political expediency and opportunism.

The fact is that two populist candidates were victorious in Indiana today. Although the politics of both may be polar opposites, the theme that unites them is that both political parties are totally out of touch with the concerns of ordinary Americans.
The main stream corporate media seem clueless as to the appeal of Sanders and Trump. It's obviously not a good year for establishment politicians but the media, as usual, is behind the curve.

That the Republican race for the nomination has ended before the Democratic race comes as a bit of a shock to those who not so long ago foresaw a possible multi-ballot affair in Cleveland. The outcome for each party may be clear but it is the Dems whose runner-up is proving more difficult to dispatch. Clinton now must deal with a two-front campaign, while Trump can focus exclusively on her.

Allocating time and resources will present challenges for the Clinton campaign. Every time she loses a state to Sanders by anything but a huge margin, her odds of winning the nomination actually increase but her general election prospects probably suffer. Hopefully, by the time we get to Philadelphia, the Sanders supporters will have been encouraged by their leader to throw the full weight of their support behind Hillary Clinton. And that had better happen in November because GOP turnout in the primaries has eclipsed Democratic turnout.

Whether or not Bernie Sanders is doing Hillary Clinton's campaign a favor or not remains to be seen. Usually, a party comes together at their convention but.... Young people engaging in this process for the first time and feeling the Bern, are going to be an important voice come the summer and fall.
Everybody gets it man,....lol

...have dumped the nut job.

Yes, but only in favor of another nut job.

Is that you, Ted?

All kidding aside, this comment is symptomatic of one of the fundamental problems that, allowed to roam free, is currently eating this country alive. You can see it in Ted Cruz and in others besides good 'ol "Pundit" here. Donald Trump in his "Lyin' Ted" comment has somewhat isolated it as well. But rather than being about "lying'" the problem has much more to do with a sort of willful ignorance that has pervaded a certain segment of the electorate.

To isolate it you only have to ask yourself a series of questions based upon this comment:

What profligate spending?
What apologizing for America?
What overreaching use of executive power?

A certain segment of the American populace, BOTH RIGHT AND LEFT, has simply abandoned any pretense of seeing facts that are arrayed before them and instead view the world through assumptions that fit their worldview. It is frankly frightening.

So, Obama dragged us out of the worst recession since the 1930s, is beloved throughout the rest of the world and worked--without any help from the Republican Congress--to bring help to the unemployed, and he is the villain of your piece? Must be living in a parallel universe.
On what grounds?

Those Democrats and Cruz haters who are gleeful that Trump is now the presumptive nominee and allegedly easy pickings for Hillary in the general should take serious pause. Obama's 8 years of over reaching executive power, profligate spending, and apologizing for America at every turn has weakened us on the national stage and unleashed a new revolution amongst the angry, the unemployed, and the hopeless youth of our nation. Hence, the birth of the likes of the populist Trump.
I find myself in the unfortunate position of having to hold my nose and vote for this reality show candidate not because I like or agree with his policies but because he is a better choice than Mrs. Clinton who is on the verge of federal indictment and possible incarceration. It is a sad day in American politics.
That's easy to say if you don't have a Uterus.

Trump's ascension in modern day politics is eerily reminiscent of Mussolini in Italy and Hitler in Germany, both democratically elected. Thomas Jefferson stated that the price of freedom is eternal vigilance. We have been sleepwalking. We have come to believe that our Freedom is a God granted gift. We are mistaken. It is something those before us earned with untold sacrifice, and entrusted to us. Too many people have sacrificed too much for us to just surrender our Constitution and Democracy to this meglomaniac.
Hillary is not a monster and is, in fact qualified to be president. Bernie is OK, but she is the most qualified. Hands down.
Wait till the general.  He hasn't won yet.

Cruz could never capture votes anywhere but Texas and mid America.  He is completely out of touch with the rest of the country.  His distortion of facts, his childish behavior in the Senate, and his weak credentials for anything more than a junior senator are enough to crush his ambitions for national office.  His choice of Fiorina is a perfect example of a bumbling drifter.

The reason Ted Cruz lost isn't because of Donald Trump or anybody else. The guy is a self-righteous, sanctimonious creep - a cross-breed between Elmer Gantry, Joseph McCarthy and the Pillsbury Doughboy. The thunderous, apocalyptic, whiny overtones he uses are deliberate. He aspires not to be President, but Torquemada. He has damaged the full faith and credit of the U.S Government, cost taxpayers millions through his televised histrionic shutdowns of government, and is utterly despised within his own party.

He wants you to believe that up is down, down is up, white is black, black white, and yes, among other things, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton will not rest until 14-year-old boys finally get to shower with little girls in transgender bathrooms all over the land.

The man was a sickening toad, and ultimately, millions saw just that. His histrionic, manipulative voice and pasty little face will not be missed.
